review_title: A sweat shop with horrible politics
pros: The individuals that CLO serves are all amazing. You form bonds with them that become very hard to break which is why I stayed as long as I did. They all love learning new life skills, and you can feel their appreciation for you when they smile.
cons: Upper management is terrible and greedy. They will work you to the point of having your nerves shot. You can ask for support and specifically state what you need, and upper management still sits back and does nothing. Lower management does all the work (lower management being Team Leads and FTCs). Home Coaches are always using PAID time to do their personal agendas such as going to school or going to get their hair done. Don't bother them, they will get mad. Upper management will do anything to shut you up, then get mad when you aren't talking. Everyone is underpaid. The list can go on, so just stay clear of this place. They need new Upper Management that actually cares about the individuals and the employees.

review_title: Go to cottonwood instead
pros:
-lots of freedom and independence 
-some of your consumers will be the best people you will ever meet
-you never have to bring your own meals, unless you want to. 
-sometimes you get to do some really cool activities on the job
-weekly paychecks
cons:
-rate of pay is extremely low considering the work that is expected of you 
-management does not hide the fact that that they value money much more than they value their employees or their consumers 
-there are more often than not consumers that are not only verbally abusive, but also physically
-I have been hit, but, pinched, scratched, punched, verbally abused, and have had someone spit on my face. 
-I have permanent scars on my arms from consumer abuse
-some consumers will be the worst people you will ever meet
This job would not seem so bad if they payed you for the work you do. The rate of pay to start should easily be $15 an hour, not $9.50. There is no shift differential for the weekends, so there isn't any incentive to work weekends. CLO is often so short staffed the you will be asked to work upwards of 5 days a week, and your shifts will almost always be a 12 hour shift. I have never worked anywhere  where I was made to feel so obligated to work so much overtime. You have to put in requests for days off at least a month in advance, but the chances are slim that you will ever get your requested days off. You are much better off never working for CLO. Cottonwood is a much better employer, and care provider to consumers.

review_title: Great place to work and make a difference
job_title: Direct Care Professional in Lawrence, KS
pros: This agency has made a very impressive effort to truly integrate people with developmental disabilities in the community. It's a very gtratifying job as you really make a difference in the lives of severely disabled people. What makes it great is the teaching component - this is not babysitting - you are actually teaching life skills. I worked for eight straight years at CLO as a teaching counselor/direct care professional and although the starting pay was not high, was given plenty of opportunities for career advancement. I really enjoyed seeing small improvements almost on a daily basis in the skill set of the folks I was teaching. Like with any other job, if you stick around and be professional, good things will happen.  If you develop a good relationship with a client (which is inevitable if you are a caring person) you can join their EFT program which has incredible benefits (financial and otherwise). I've had experiences with other such agencies and the difference in training, services, care, etc. is dramatic. Also, there are numerous benefits, incl. reduced gym membership, dental ins., really good paid time off system, etc. I think, what's really imprortant is to keep in mind that you are not working with machines or products -  this is a job that requires you to help people...very fragile and yet wonderful people. I would recommend this job, but only to people who actually are serious about what they do in life and actually care for the less fortunate.
cons: The starting pay rate for direct care professionals needs to increase

review_title: Challenging job but extremely rewarding!
pros: This is an organization where you know everyone's heart is in the right place, and even on your worst day you know you have done something truly meaningful in the lives of individuals who's lives have been greatly enhanced by your work. The folks we serve here are unique and interesting, and the experience is humbling to say the least. Your supervisors here are willing to listen to you and take your ideas and they are always willing to step in and help or offer more training. All the home coaches and team leaders have to provide the same direct care as you do and are really experts at it.
cons: The pay is low, but normal for the industry unfortunately. $9.50 to $10 an hour to start, so a little more that you get paid at Cottonwood IF you can be super flexible and work multiple homes. Pay is the same at Trinity in home care, Sheltered Living in Topeka, and other places. Pay should be way higher in my opinion, and they don't offer health care (they do have dental and life insurance and paid time off). Communication sometimes sucks, it's hard to get upper management to call back in a timely manner, and sometimes my schedule changes and I haven't been talked to about it and all kinds of other changes happen suddenly.

review_title: A job I wish I hadn't taken.
pros:
CLO is very good to it's clients.  They are treated well and, for the most part, are happy.
Family Teachers do not have to pay rent or utilities (electric and gas) so that does help to offset the salary of $6.55 per hour and work week of 55 hours.
cons:
As a Family Teacher, you and your spouse are told you will work 55 hours a week a piece, together, which is 4 day of 12 hours each plus meetings and doctors appointments and paperwork time outside of that.  My husband and I were supposed to work Sun-Wed from 7am to 7 pm.  The reality?  We worked Sun-Wed, at least 7-7, we also worked at LEAST half a day Thursday, often all day, and were often called in to work Friday or Saturday.  
We were told that we would have good support and classes in order to get our certification, which comes with a financial bonus, and yet every time we signed up for the mandatory class in order to become certified (a class taught BY CLO) we were told that we couldn't take it because there was no one to cover our shift OR we could take the all day class on Fridays, all Fridays, for two months and that they MIGHT have babysitting for our daughter (at the time 3 years old) or she could just be in class with us.
CLO also claims to be very family friendly and that you are welcome to have your children with you while you work.  And yet if we spent any time dealing or helping our 3 year old while working, even if the clients were all busy or happy, we could get in trouble.  I also got pregnant while working and almost immediately after announcing the pregnancy things got strained at CLO.
I had very bad morning sickness, throwing up enough to need to see the doctor, and I had to get a doctor's note in order to be let off duty, for 2 days, from doing heavy lifting of clients.  Not long before my due date, my husband and I were accused by our supervisor of Neglect of clients and mismanagement of funds.  ANE (Abuse, Neglect, Exploitation) officer reviewed everything and found no such issues. 
Two weeks later, we were suspended from duty and told that we were being moved to an "On-Call" position where we would fill in for vacation and sick leave for other couples.  Since our position included a place to live, we were moved to a vacant location.  We were given one week to pack up our house.  This was two weeks before my due date.
The week I was due, we were informed that once I came off Maternity Leave (we had been with the company one and a half years by now) my husband would be working Sun-Wed and I would be working Wed-Sat.  We would have no days off together.  And we "might" be able to take the children with us to SOME of the houses but if not, well, that's why they made sure we wouldn't both be working at the same time.  You know, except for Wednesday.
We quit while I was still on Maternity.  CLO has a reputation, among those who have worked there, for chasing out couples when they are expecting.  I know personally of three cases of employees being fired or forced out either while pregnant or shortly after giving birth.

You will not be unscathed, even if you think you are following the rules. The management team will do ANYTHING to not be blamed for a problem, even when it is solely their fault.
